Posts.Content: Hi Sascha Rose, I got my BNF out (British National Formulare - an index of all medicines licensed in the UK), so here goes: It seems that Letrozole is preferred when the aim is breast conservation, so as small a lumpectomy as possible rather than a full mastectomy, The BNF (March 2011) also says that they should not be used for pre-menopausal women. The list of side effects for Letrozole is twice as long as for Anastrozole. Mainly nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, drowsiness, hot flushes, vaginal bleeding & dryness, and hair loss. Letrozole has the added bonus of high blood pressure, eye problems, abdo & tumour pain, arthritis, oedema and rarely embolisms. Letrozole and Anastrozole are both non-steroidal aromatase inhibitors, that means they bind certain hormone receptors and stop them from doing their work (in this case cancer cells multiplying). I hope this answers your question (I kind of wish I hadn't looked now, because I've got no idea what's coming at me yet....) Hugs! xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone know the difference between Letrozole and Anastrazole please...

Posts.Content: Thank you, thank you, thank you for this thread!!! I have been worrying myself about this endlessly! Although it's at least a year till I will be considered for recon, I have been thinking of not having rads because of the tissue damage they cause and I definitely don't want an LD because I am a nurse and I need the strength in my shoulder for that, But now I am thinking the possibilities are endless! Thanks again!
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: I did have weird dreams last week (first FEC), but totally didn't connect it! How funny!
Posts.Title: Weird dreams

Posts.Content: I don't know, I have to say I STILL feel invincible even though my husband died of bowel cancer, my dad of tongue cancer and I had the dreaded BC. I would hate to think that my friends have to walk on eggshells just in case they say the wrong thing! In fact, last night I was telling a friend about my hair slowly coming out and that I didn't need to pull hard for it to come off. She didn't believe me and put her hand in my hair and pulled - and had a whole handful, of course. Was it insensitive of her? Sure. Was I upset? Not really. It's going to come out anyway and at the time it was funny. She's a really good friend and will be there for practical and just listening help. I won't become oversensitive. People don't say things to deliberately upset me. They ask questions because they are working things out in their own heads what they can do, how I may feel etc. And I am always honest with my replies; I will say when I feel rubbish and I will say when I need help and I will say when I am fine.
Posts.Title: so annoyed with crass comments

Posts.Content: Hi SaschaRose, this is horrible! Yes, kick up a fuss! Please! I did when someone just walked in the treatment room when I had the tracing of the nodes done. She claimed she was 'allowed' and I said she should at least knock. Now really, I didn't mind (I have a very healthy image of myself, even now with just the one breast), but I am very aware that not everyone is as assertive as I am and therefore I will make a fuss, so that the next time they think twice about doing this to anybody. Am now dreading rads - not happy about these anyway, and now being confronted with a tattoo???? What on earth for?
Posts.Title: Is RADS always like this?

Posts.Content: Fresh pineapple! Really, it's the best thing ever! I have a weird taste in my mouth and pineapple helps soooo much! (It's also the only thing I can taste properly). In general fruit and veg are tastier than anything else, chocolate after mouthwash (even hours after mouthwash!) is vile. For the 'fog' I recommend very light entertainment, like just the radio on. Nothing too taxing - I found it hard even having a normal conversation and concentrating on getting to the loo in time! Also my friends have deviced a rota: the first five days after chemo I get meals cooked for the family, I have a designated washer, one ironer and a couple of people for houswork once a week. If I need company for appointments I can take my pick. :-) This is good on so many levels: I get to chill and to concentrate on my studies. The children don't feel neglected. All my friends feel they are helping (and they are!). My mum (who lives abroad) knows I am well looked after.
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Thanks for the reassurance, Yvonne! I felt like a Zombie for about four days after the chemo, but some reckon that's down to the antisickness tablets, so I'll cut them down this time (not feeling sick, so I'll give it a try). I am very lucky indeed, I won't have to have the TAX, just FEC for six cycles (and a third of that will be done by tomorrow night, yay), then rads (if I agree to that, I don't really see the point) and then Herceptin. Ah, and then hormones. I was positive for everything I think! I will make a big thing of the Zombie-state I was in. The baldness can speak for itself - I don't mind that so much, only it's soooo cold!!! :-) Hope you'll sail through the TAX the same xxx
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Yvonne, I am so glad I am not the only one! Although I'm only having no. 2 FEC tomorrow and no hair left.... I haven't been sick either, and the tiredness the first few days after chemo was horrible. I am seeing the oncologist today and am petrified that she'll decide to up my dose! Fingers crossed!
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne, I asked the oncologist why rads and she said it reduces the risk of recurrence at the site it started by 30 %. So I suppose I'll roll with it. In my case they wouldn't do it at the same time as chemo. My breastcare nurse - who is brilliant - understands why I don't want to waste time and immediately started asking about earliest and latest rad appointments, so I can work them around my placement. My chemo is at 11 tomorrow, don't know yet about the next one. The lot after that will be afternoon, but it will be fine. :-)
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Aw, Mary, thank you so much for sharing this! Sadly, my husband died of bowel cancer four years ago, but regarding the hair thing I hold on to when he said very soon after we'd met and I complained about a 'bad hair day' that Hair Is Overrated. I am about to take the clippers to mine now. As my hair started coming out (I am day 18 after first FEC) and I was speaking to a friend about it the other day, I said it didn't take much tugging. So she put her hand in my hair and pulled and of course lots came out! We did have a good laugh about it and I like it that she doesn't treat me with kid gloves! Well done you for getting through - I shall have new hair in the new year! :-)
Posts.Title: A post chemo smile!

Posts.Content: That depends very much on your nurse and on your trust policy. If your breast care nurse is sympathetic, she can go through your notes with you. But many 'medicals' are kind of aloof and protective of 'the notes' (I had an actual argument with my surgeon when I said I wanted to see ALL my notes!); I think they feel patients who ask to read them don't trust them. In 'my' trust you have to fill in an application to see your notes. The form asks for 'which episode' you want to see (stupid question, really. ALL episodes, but they seem to want dates). There is a fee of up to £ 50 and when that payment has gone through they have 40 days to send a copy of all the notes. Possibly in your hospital trust it doesn't cost anything, or it may cost more. Ask your breast care nurse or contact the PAL team, they will be able to tell you your exact procedure. So far I have not officially applied to see all mine, but I sneak a look at them when I am left alone with them. You are entitled to a copy of all your reports and all the letters passing between consultants and other health care professionals without charge anyway; just asking someone to copy you in should be enough. Hope that helps! x
Posts.Title: Patient Notes

Posts.Content: Thank you, Suzie, that has answered my question perfectly! I really don't like the thought of loosing my eyelashes, so I suppose I will have to get some training in how to put on falsies! My actual hair I am not too bothered about, I think scarves will be the way forward for me - I've done amateur dramatics and find wigs very itchy. I like your idea of going to a 'posh shop' for some training! I think I'll do that when the time comes. :-) Thanks again! xx
Posts.Title: Hairy Question

Posts.Content: Ah now here's the thing: I had right MX, they cleared everything with a 'good' margin and the lymphs were clear. So the chemo I am having at the moment is only 'just in case' there's a micro-bit that's slipped through the net anywhere at all in my body. From what I understand the rationale for having radiotherapy is exactly the same: 'just in case' there's a micro-bit in the chest wall. I am already a bit of the 'if it ain't broke, don't fix it' brigade, so don't like having chemo, but everyone was on at me, so I am going through this anyway. Do I really want another lot of just in case when chemo will supposedly get rid of all that already? Also this means an extra three weeks out and I don't want to give over any more time to this stupid thing that is trying to run my life. Seeing oncologist tomorrow... I almost feel sorry for her! :-)
Posts.Title: Rarer Side effects of Radiotherapy to chest wall

Posts.Content: Just a quick question: with chemo I've put on just over a stone and now all my trousers don't fit. Will I be able to get rid of the extra weight or do I have to invest in a new wardrobe?    P.S.: I was lucky enough to not mind too much about the weight itself, I just don't want to spend so much money!
Posts.Title: Weight?

Posts.Content: This is probably a really silly question, and please feel free to laugh at me if it is: I appreciate that I will probably loose my hair with chemo (this cold cap business sounds too horrible to even contemplate, I hate being cold!), but: Does ALL hair fall out? I mean not only potentially all hair on the top of your head, but what about eyebrows and eyelashes (I'd find that a lot harder to cope with) and underarms and legs (wouldn't mind that at all, haha)?
Posts.Title: Hairy Question

Posts.Content: Sascha, you make me laugh! Lady Garden! Hahaha :-) Alas, I have no partner to please - my husband died of bowel cancer. (so I am even more determined to beat this rubbish!). Will look into the feel good workshop thing though, how do i find it? x
Posts.Title: Hairy Question

Posts.Content: Hi Kay, I am so sorry! I think a big part of the problem is that people feel so helpless and don't know what to do. My husband died of bowel cancer four and a half years ago, and we had a little bit of me withdrawing (I think it's self protection), but he spoke to me about it and we fixed it. I learned to do his syringe driver and did most of his nursing needs so I was able to do stuff for him and that helped tremendously. Now I have had a mastectomy and am in the middle of chemo myself, I am letting everybody help as much as I can bear - more because people need to feel they are helping than me needing needing the help, if you know what I mean. Friends have set up a cooking rota for chemo week and they come and clean for me once a week. Hope that helps a little. Hugs x
Posts.Title: Relationship problems

Posts.Content: Hey Sassy, I hope I am not butting in, just you sound like me: I was diagnosed with bc last week (don't know about lymphs yet) and will have a mastectomy on 26th June. I am very cross at all this (like you in your blog which I now can't find anymore!) and thought we could do this together...?? Have sent you a friend request (ah, this is like fb....:-P)
Posts.Title: People's reactions

Posts.Content: Yes, Tamsin, I agree with the other two. I have a bunch of friends who have come up with a rota for cooking during chemo week, and cleaning, ironing etc. once a week while I am having treatment. Very often I will say, don't clean, just talk to me (which usually gets me a reply of 'first I'll clean and then I'll talk to you'). If I need anything else done, like the grass cut or one of the children taken to the orthodontist, I have a list of people I can ask.  I am very blessed - I don't suffer that much from the chemo, but my friends make it possible for me to concentrate on my studies. And it is good to let them help, also for them. One said to me 'and you MUST let us do stuff because then we feel like we are helping' which is important for them, too. :-)
Posts.Title: What to do to help

Posts.Content: Drinking lots definitely helps! I have not tried the fasting thing, I think 60 hours before is probably overdoing it and if you feel like eating the day after chemo that's cool (steroids make you want food anyway) as long as it's healthy. 84 hours fasting sounds an awful lot to me and you do need to make sure you get all your nutrients. Obviously as I haven't done the fasting I am no proper judge (although I wish I had yesterday - had chemo yesterday and was promptly sick in the night.). I don't get that many bad side effects though. Hope that helps a little. x
Posts.Title: Fasting Before & After Chemo

Posts.Content: Hey, it's probably a bit of an anticlimax. But it also sounds like you might suffer from a bit of depression. Go and see your GP about it. I am 'only' half way through chemo, so I've not experienced that phase yet. Hope you'll feel better soon. xxx
Posts.Title: Had all treatment & feel terrible!

Posts.Content: Hi Pat, I have had a quick look at the latest research (I had a lot to do with dressings in my last placement as student nurse). It is very well known that honey dressings will make a wound sterile, and there is good evidence that the bacteria within the honey promote wound healing. (I've seen honey work fantastically, but that was not on burns). They should be used for only a few weeks at a time, so after two or three weeks, something else should be used. However, honey dressings are very expensive, so they might not be on the first choice dressing list for your trust. Discuss it with your nurse or your GP (the nurse probably knows better). I think there are also alginate dressings - equally expensive, and the most recent research I found showed that honey works better. Hope you get this sorted! Petra x
Posts.Title: dressings for rad burns

Posts.Content: Why? x

Will have a think on wording and then suggest they do a piece with me - (I am quaking in my boots as I say this, but I will do it) and obviously, if anyone else is up for it (maybe the could do a 'chest shot' only without faces????) please join in. Is it ok to put the link to this thread in the email?
Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Content: Ok, I will. Have you got a link of where I start looking?
Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Content: Yay, Annie!!!! Go Girl!!! So pleased for you!!! xxx
Posts.Title: never thought would be so happy to have surgery!!

Posts.Content: Hey, I don't come here often enough to have read all your bits about alternatives, but I would be very interested. At the moment I feel so well (just post mx) that I am wondering why on earth I should want to make myself really ill with chemo. Also I am very dubious about hormone therapy and herceptin is a definite no for me (Sorry to all the people who fought to make it widely available). It is always good to know what else there is. Also, this is supposed to be about patient centredness and if your choice is no chemo then everyone should support you in that. So please don't go anywhere!
Posts.Title: Not sure if I still belong here or not?

Posts.Content: FEC for me was really no problem. I felt a bit muddled with the first lot, and then just tired for a couple of days after the rest of the cycles. Couldn't concentrate on academic studying, but could have worked if they'd let me on the wards. :-) From what I hearm Tax is a lot worse!  Am starting on Herceptin on Friday and am very pleased to hear that you seemed to find that ok, because I am scared of that one! :-)
Posts.Title: Taxol Herceptin then FEC

Posts.Content: Hi, what is a cold cap? - i've not started treatment yet, so I know nothing.... x
Posts.Title: First chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hey, 26th June seems to be mastectomy day. It's mine then, too. I am really surprised that you have alredy been asked to sign a consent form! I've not even thought about this and have to say your post has made me feel a little ouch! Obviously, I can't give you any proper advise, I can just say I know exactly how you feel. At the moment I'm kind of ignoring the being-single-breasted bit and trying to focus on all the other stuff. Sending you big hugs - and I have heard that it's ok to feel sorry for oneself every now and then. xxxx
Posts.Title: rambling thoughts

Posts.Content: Lorraine, Thank you so much for your post!!!! It never occurred to me to mention my mental health status to anyone! At the moment (2 weeks post mx) I am fighting for uni to let me into placement before I start chemo (don't know exactly what that will be, find out Monday). I am going mad at home thinking I am falling behind with my studies. I've send you a friend request - if you don't mind being my moral support? Thanks again for posting this!
Posts.Title: Will I be able to work through treatment?

Posts.Content: I wonder if more people could put their experience up? I am studying (nursing of all things!) and I appreciate that I may not be able to start the next placement with the rest of my year (I am lagging three weeks behind with the current one, due to the mastectomy), but I'd at least like to attend all the lectures from September to - I think - November. Chemo is due to start at some point in August although I don't know the details yet. With others putting their experiences across I have an idea of worst case / best case scenarios... Thanks everyone!
Posts.Title: Will I be able to work through treatment?

Posts.Content: Starting my own chemo on 3rd September, so still have my hair. Met a lot of FEC ladies at the look good feel better thing and they had all lost their hair, bar one lady who had some fluff left on the top. My children are freaking out about the hair thing, too, and they are teenagers! My daughter (14) is insisting that I shall have a wig... I am quite determined to be very silly with the whole thing - they don't like that idea at all! :P
Posts.Title: FEC and hair loss

Posts.Content: Oh Annie, I am so sorry you are having such a struggle. When I was diagnosed they figured my lump was about 5 x 3. They first asked ME what I thought we should do (possibly because the thought as a nurse I'd have some insight). I said mastectomy straight away, as this seemed quite big to me. They totally agreed, but did say there was the possibility of having chemo first to try and have a lumpectomy instead, but they would recommend a mastectomy straight away, too. I find it so strange that different trusts act so differently. Big hug to you xxx
Posts.Title: will they be able to do surgery on a BIG lump

Posts.Content: Hi Danielle, I have all this still in front of me, so I can't really give you any tips. I am surprised at you being so sick though, did they not offer you any antiemetics to stop that? Good for you to have a holiday before the chemo - I won't get that luxury, I am hoping to complete my placement before that... Hugs xx
Posts.Title: had my lumpectomy yesturday

Posts.Content: Radiotherapy didn't make me tired at all - I worked normal shifts during it (8.5 hours) and long days (12.5 hour shifts) as soon as I didn't have to turn up for the rads anymore.  Also I had a mastectomy in June and went back to work on long days exactly three weeks after - only because occupational health wouldn't even consider seeing me before that.  :-) Everyone is different....
Posts.Title: time off work

Posts.Content: I am really surprised at the supplies people have been bringing! How long did people spend in hospital? From my perspective the mastectomy was a real doddle (haven't had chemo yet, so no comparison). I went to theatre at 4, got to the ward about 6. I found texting really tiring for the next couple of hours (I'd send one text and feel exhausted!), but the MOBILE is definitely a must bring. I got up to use the toilet straight away - the first time a nurse walked me there, but I walked back on my own. The drains came out at ten the next morning and I was discharged (including letter) at 11. On my list to take would be: the mobile and charger, pyjamas, a sports bra (or a post surgery one, def. one without wire), wash stuff & tooth brush and if you want a soft towel (as opposed to the NHS ones) bring that. Oh, and I had a uni friend (we're studying nursing and were on placement) bring me decent coffee as she was placed at the hospital I was at. Of course, if you are scheduled for a longer stay than just overnight, you'll need more for entertainment, laptop/books etc. and some nice treats, like chocolate. Three weeks later I started my placement (because of the op I am behind everyone else now) on a heavy neuro rehab ward and I am absolutely fine. So what you need to leave behind is your worries. Wishing you all the best!
Posts.Title: Scheduled for MX on Friday - a few questions

Posts.Content: You'll be ok with just non wired bras for a couple of weeks - I only just got my 'chicken filet' insert and my mx was in July. You'll probably stay in over night unless you're first on the list. My drains came out within 24 hours after the op, and it was fine, but I know of others who had them in for a few days, so I guess everyone's different (Don't you just hate that there's nothing clear cut?!). I didn't have lots of lymphs removed, just the two that were within the area and one extra one. I am a nosey so and so and looked pretty much straight away - the bruising was amazing! It went all the way down to my hip and I had fun scaring people with it. But maybe I'm just a bit mad. The whole thing wasn't that bad an experience, I have to say. You'll be fine!
Posts.Title: impending masectomy

Posts.Content: The oncologist should not have been dismissive whatever his/her reasons. You deserve a proper explanation why they recommend one treatment over another, how else are you going to make an informed decision? I had surgery first of all, am starting on FEC on Monday. Then they want me to have rads, however, if FEC is supposed to kill all stray cells, what's the point in that? I agree with Sue: do something really nice xxx
Posts.Title: FEC not working so moving on to T. Anyone else had this?

Posts.Content: That is so true SaxxyD - I went wig trying today and was getting more and more upset (we had hacked off my hair just a couple of hours before because it became impossible), but the minute the right one came along it was fine! Look Good Feel Better was fun! And by Christmas I'll be done with chemo! Yay!
Posts.Title: Just told I need chemo!

Posts.Content: My drains came out after about 16 hours. The most I've heard them stay in is about three days. Also I disagree with 'you don't have movement in your arm for a few weeks' - I went back to work nursing on a heavy rehab ward exactly three weeks after the mastectomy and occupational health had certified me full movement. I believe everyone is different. Front button tops are easier, I agree, although I personally wasn't bothered at all. It probably also depends on node clearance etc. Good luck with everything! :-)
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: I have given tons of clexane injections and have never heard anyone mention they've had side effects (although I am sure there can be some). At the same time, I have talked people out of having it because I thought it over the top treatment, eg. very young fit girls after minor surgery. Why are you given it?
Posts.Title: clexane

Posts.Content: It is, but what do you mean everyone had to have it? I haven't had any at all, not even after mx (not that I would have taken it). It is given when there is a greater risk of clotting.
Posts.Title: clexane

Posts.Content: Wow, Annie, 4 weeks after MX sounds a bit excessive! :-) I supposed different trusts use different guidelines - I never had any after MX.
Posts.Title: clexane

Posts.Content: Ah, tempting fate implies that you believe in fate. Do you really? Have a good think about it. Skiing and BC have definitely not got anything to do with each other! PLEASE GO ON YOUR CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY AND ENJOY IT!!!! You deserve it so much!!! Sending you a BIG hug xxx
Posts.Title: Tempting fate....ridiculous

Posts.Content: The risk of lymphoma is one in four, I've been told. I have met a lady with lymphoma who said it's not so bad. I understand though, that you want to hang on to them - they're your immune system after all. Could they just take another couple of lymphnodes to test? I know this means a potential third op, but maybe that's an option? I am thinking the same about 'chemo kills the lurking cancer' and having rads as well as chemo. Sorry if this is not helpful xxx
Posts.Title: Remove or Not Remove Underarm Lymph Nodes

Posts.Content: I have not had any experience like yours and am so sorry to hear this!   Four months with cancer is a very very long time; cancer can be very aggressive and grow rapidly. So I think you should seriously consider a negligence suit - and I am not normally in favour of that! I agree that you should start with PALS at your hospital and they should be able to point you in the right direction. However, I would also consider seeking legal advice straight away, especially while you have the energy! Hope all will go really well for you! xxx
Posts.Title: Seriously Delayed Mamo Results for Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: How strange that everyone would call their chemo nurse for thrush! I would find the closest chemist and get some Canesten and then see my GP on Monday. Thrush is quite common during chemo - not only 'down below', but also in your mouth. Nothing to panic about. :-) And please everybody - don't jump on me - it's just what I would do. Ringing the chemo nurse is fine, and she won't mind!
Posts.Title: Embarassing, but I need relief!
